statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado State 74, BYU 67
article.story: FORT COLLINS, Colo. (AP) -- With its leading scorer held in check and second-leading scorer out with an injury, Colorado State looked to its future to deliver its first conference win. Freshman Jason Smith scored 19 points and Sean Morris added 12 points and eight rebounds as Colorado State ended a two-game losing streak with a 74-67 victory over BYU Saturday. Matt Nelson was held to 11 points and 10 rebounds for Colorado State (9-6, 1-1 Mountain West) but extended his string of double-figure scoring games to 13. "Jason and Sean really gave us a lift," Colorado State coach Dale Layer said. "I have been crazy about Sean all year, but he missed six games and it is hard to build both his confidence and our confidence in him." An ankle injury sidelined Matt Williams to open up playing time for Smith. Morris gained time when point guard Dwight Boatner decided to leave the team earlier in the week for personal reasons. "They told us that as freshmen we have to come out and have energy and be hyped up," Smith said. "If your teammates have confidence in you, you have to have confidence in yourself." Austin Ainge led BYU (6-11, 0-2) with 25 points on five 3-pointers. Mike Hall had 11 points as the Cougars lost their third in four games. BYU finished shooting 35 percent and a dreadful first half where they were 7-for-37 overall and 4-for-19 on 3-pointers. "We are playing well enough to lose," BYU coach Steve Cleveland said. "Offensively we were abysmal in the first half and our execution with ties wasn't very good." Trailing by 10 at the half, the Cougars scored the first six points of the second half and took a 43-42 lead with 10:58 left on baskets by Ainge and Garner Meads. But Smith took over, scoring 13 points over a seven-minute stretch including a 3-pointer with 3:42 remaining to put Colorado State ahead 64-54. After the Rams missed four free throws, two 3-pointers by Ainge got BYU within 70-67 with 45 seconds left. Two free throws each by Jon Rakiecki and Nelson sealed the game. The Cougars double-teamed and denied Nelson in the first half, but Colorado State didn't need him in building a 32-22 lead at the half. Morris came off the bench to score four points in a 12-2 run to close the period after Ainge tied the game at 20 with a 3-pointer with 5:48 left. BYU hurt itself shooting 19 percent and going 2-for-13 over an eight-minute stretch. The Rams overcame 12 turnovers in the first 20 minutes, including ones on their first four possessions, but were near flawless when Morris came on. "We were ugly again and I'm tired of this where we play hard at the end, get close at the end and come up short," Ainge said. "We have to figure out a way to play well the first 20 minutes like we do the last 20 minutes."
